entry.title: Re: Dynamic value for @title annotation - is it possible?
entry.content:
Hey, there is no official solution, but I guess it's possible to implement some hacks. Proceed at your own risk.

So as you noted it's not really possible to use other JSONModels.  The source must be a ResourceModel. 

So what you could do is creating a second ResourceModel (to keep the original ResourceModel hack free) (could be named i18nDyn or similar) in the manifest.json and also a new folder (i18nDyn) with properties files in each language (i18nDyn_de.properties etc). It should contain the label keys which you reference in your annotation.

E.g. add an annotation country @title: '{i18nDyn>country}' (uses the new ResourceModel) to your data and add a line country=DUMMY to your i18nDyn.properties file.

Now here comes the ugly part: Replace the DUMMY values with actual dynamic values. To do so implement a lifecycle hook (like onInit) in your controller or Component and add the following code

const bundle = this.getOwnerComponent().getModel('i18nDyn').getResourceBundle();
// access private properties of bundle. ugly and dangerous!
const properties = bundle.aPropertyFiles[0].mProperties;
// modify the values of the keys
properties.country = "Germany";
// now "country" is not "DUMMY" anymore

 This should then work in p13n dialogs as well as regular tables and filter bars.

entry.title: Re: Query on Replenishment strategy in storage type
entry.content:
When you trigger replenishment, the system creates a replenishment request (essentially a requirement). The request quantity is calculated based on the bin‚Äôs stock at that moment (0 ‚Üí max 200 in your example). If you don‚Äôt choose Immediate WT Creation, the request sits in the queue until you later create the WT.

This setting tells the system: when creating the WT, recalculate the required quantity based on current stock in the bin. However, this recalculation only works if the replenishment request is flagged to allow adjustment. In practice, EWM often does not reduce the WT quantity if you‚Äôve already manually changed the bin stock, because the replenishment request is still for 200 units. The system assumes the request is valid and creates a WT to fulfill it.

Having said that why you saw 200 instead of 150 is because, the replenishment request was created for 200 units when the bin was empty. Even though you manually put away 50 units, the request itself was not updated. At WT creation, the system still honored the original request quantity. The ‚ÄúNew Quantity at WT Creation‚Äù setting doesn‚Äôt override the request ‚Äî it only recalculates if the request type and strategy allow dynamic adjustment.

So check the below areas

In customizing under Activate Replenishment Strategies, check if the strategy allows recalculation at WT creation. Some strategies like planned vs. automatic behave differently.

Verify whether the request is set to be ‚Äúflexible‚Äù or ‚Äúfixed.‚Äù If fixed, the WT will always match the request quantity.

Ensure that the stock check at WT creation is active. In some versions, this requires additional customizing in the replenishment control parameters.

It is a nice story. However somehow biased. You focus mainly on the purchasing process. In my opinion what MM is all about is inventory management, i.e. inventory planning and controlling. In other words making sure we stock what is needed but no more than that. Having said that, in my opinion the heart of MM is inventory controlling and document analysis reports and above all MRP planning and MRP exceptions.

If you focus on purchasing only, you lose all the automation that SAP provides. Purchases need to be plan manually outside of the system and ERP becomes an overpriced cash register - transactions are just registered there while management is still done in spreadsheets.

entry.title: Re: The Complete Guide to Calling Actions in UI5 with Custom Code
entry.content:
@MattHarding I believe these "single action per file" controllers created by the guided development do more harm than good. Maybe you should refactor this to a real controller (extension). 

Name of the file is now Something.controller.js (and not Something.js)

sap.ui.define([
    'sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension'
], function (ControllerExtension, MessageBox) {
    'use strict';

    return ControllerExtension.extend('provide.real.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt', {
        // this section allows to extend lifecycle hooks or hooks provided by Fiori elements
        override: {
            onInit: function () {
                // blabla
            }
        },

        onPressRefresh: function (oContext, aSelectedContexts) {
            this.base.getExtensionAPI().refresh();
        }
    });
});

This way you have a real instance of something class like, you can access instance variables, this works as expected etc. 

You can generate these controller extensions using the page map. After that if you create a custom action using guided development and pass the extension file name to the guide it will add the new method at the correct place in your controller extension.

To invoke these handlers from the manifest you have to use a little different syntax though.

"actions": {
    "print": {
        "press": ".extension.provide.real.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt.onPressPrint",
        "visible": true,
        "enabled": true,
        "requiresSelection": false,
        "text": "{@i18n>print}"
    }
}

 The full namespace to the method PLUS ".extension." as a prefix.

Also the controller extension needs to be declared in the manifest, but the page map should handle this for you. If not:

"extends": {
  "extensions": {
    "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
      "sap.fe.templates.ListReport.ListReportController": {
        "controllerName": "provide.read.namespace.ext.controller.ListReportExt"
      }
    }
  }
}

entry.title: Applying User Filters in SAP Identity Provisioning Service to Sync a Single User from MS Entra ID
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

I‚Äôm writing this blog after going through extensive SAP documentation and community articles. The purpose of this post is to explain how to apply a user filter in the SAP Identity Provisioning Service (IPS) so that only a single user gets synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID.

 

üîßRequirement

We want to sync only one specific user from Microsoft Entra ID into the target system using IPS by applying a user-level filter on the source system.

 

üìåPrerequisites

Before starting, you should have:

  • A Source System of type Microsoft Entra ID (or any other user-store source system)

  • A Target System of type Identity Authentication
    (You can choose a different target system depending on your requirement)

These systems must be configured in your SAP BTP Cloud Identity Services.

 

üîçAnalysis

When we first executed the job in Simulation Mode, we found that our Entra ID environment contained 5000+ users. Running a full sync would have immediately written all these users into the target system‚Äîwhich we wanted to avoid until we were confident.

To prevent syncing the entire user base, we decided to use the user filter property in the source system configuration.

This led us to applying a filter that would sync only one specific user, allowing us to validate the job behavior safely.

 

‚úÖSolution

Below is the property you need to configure in the Source System to sync only a single user from Entra ID (or any similar source system):

Property Name

aad.user.filter

Property Value

userPrincipalName eq 'rgera@company.com'

This filter ensures that only the user with the specified User Principal Name is retrieved and synchronized.

Refer to the screenshot in your Cloud Identity Service configuration for guidance.

 

üß™ Result

After saving the property and running the job again, only one user was successfully synchronized from Microsoft Entra ID‚Äîexactly as expected.

 

üìòAdditional Notes

IPS supports many different filter conditions. You can adapt filters based on:

  • givenName

  • mail

  • displayName

  • objectId

  • Group conditions

  • And more‚Ä¶

These filters help you fine-tune user synchronization based on your business needs.

 

ü§ùConclusion

I hope this blog helps anyone looking to apply user-level filters when running synchronization jobs in SAP Identity Provisioning Service. It‚Äôs a simple yet powerful way to limit and control the data flowing between systems‚Äîespecially in large environments.

Regards,
Rohit Gera

entry.title: Parked Supplier Invoices Only Show Vendor Line (No G/L or Cost Object Lines) in FI Apps
entry.content:
When creating a supplier invoice in SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition and saving it as complete (parked), the system only displays the vendor line item in FI apps such as Manage Journal Entries, Manage Supplier Line Items, or any of the parked-document CDS views (I_ParkedOplAcctgDocument, I_ParkedOplAcctgDocGLItem, VBSEG*-based views).

The offsetting G/L account line and its cost-object assignment (cost center, WBS, etc.)‚Äîwhich are visible in the Create Supplier Invoice app‚Äîdo not appear anywhere on the FI side while the invoice is parked. This behaviour differs from parked G/L journal entries (e.g., document type SA), where both debit and credit lines are visible immediately.

Customers often expect a full accounting preview of the parked supplier invoice in FI apps, especially when using approval workflows or during UAT. However, parked RE invoices are stored as MM parked invoice documents, and at this stage no FI document with full accounting lines exists yet. Only the vendor line is created as a parked FI item.

The complete accounting document (vendor + G/L + cost objects) is only generated after the invoice is posted, meaning FI reporting apps and CDS views cannot display the missing G/L or cost-object information during the parked phase.


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Simple understanding of Hierarchies in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics‚Äì Part 1 (Basics)
entry.content:
Accurate CDS hierarchy modeling and understanding is critical for financial reporting and operational analytics. Without well-defined hierarchies, drill-down analysis and aggregated insights become challenging. This blog demystifies hierarchy concepts in SAP S/4HANA Embedded Analytics and shows how they power SAC,Multidimensiona Reports , AFO and Datasphere scenarios.This blog will give you the basic understanding of Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana)

What This Blog Covers

  • Common hierarchy terminologies
  • Types of hierarchies in CDS Views
  • Standard hierarchies in S/4HANA
  • Why custom hierarchies matter


1. Key Terminologies-

Before diving into implementation, let‚Äôs clarify the basics:

  • Root Node : Top-most node in the hierarchy. Has No parent. Signifies the Hierarchy Structure and contains the Hierarchy metadata. A hierarchy can have several root nodes.
  • Hierarchy Node : Represents a group or element in the hierarchy.
  • Parent Node : A node that has child nodes beneath it.
  • Child Node : Belongs to a parent node.
  • Leaf Node : Lowest node in the hierarchy (end point).
  • Hierarchy Directory : Stores hierarchy definitions.
  • Siblings : Nodes sharing the same parent.
  • Hierarchy Level : Indicates depth of a node in the hierarchy. Levels can be defined as 0,1,2,3 . In S/4 EA change level based hierarchies to Parent child hierarchies .
  • Recursive Hierarchy: Nodes can reference themselves (e.g., Org Structure). Implemented using self-association in CDS.
  • Hierarchy Node Texts: These contain the descriptive names or labels associated with the hierarchy nodes, typically derived from the related master data (for example, the name or description of a General Ledger account or Product Hierarchy Description).
  • Orphan nodes, These are the nodes missing a link to a root. You can choose to ignore them, raise an error, or promote them as alternative roots using annotations like ORPHANS = ROOT

2. Example of a Hierarchy-

Company ‚Üí Product Category ‚Üí Product ‚Üí Variant Shoe Model 1

Example:

  • Company (ABC Corp)  ‚Üí Root Node -> The top most node in hierarchy (Defined via Hierarchy Directory and Root node has no parent defined)---- To be discussed in details in another Part 2.
  • Product Category (Footwear)  ‚Üí Child of Company->A Parent Node for Product but this is not the Root node(Since it has Company as a Parent Node).
  • Product (Shoes)  ‚Üí Child of Product Category->Parent Node for Variant
  • Variant (Shoe Model 1)  ‚Üí Leaf Node->Lowest Node in the hierarchy

 In SAP: For Cost Center or Profit Center hierarchy, Controlling Area could be the root node.

3. Types of Hierarchies in CDS Views-

In S/4HANA Embedded Analytics, hierarchies are modeled using CDS annotations. Most common type:

  • Parent-Child Hierarchy üîó Always recursive. Each node references its parent, forming a tree structure. Example: Cost Center hierarchy where each cost center belongs to a higher-level.

 

  • Level-Based Hierarchy üîóNot supported in S4 Hana Embedded analytics as Analytical engine supports only Parent Child Hierarchy for drill downs and aggregations.

CDS Annotation Example:

@Hierarchy.parentChild:
{ recurse:          {   parent: 'ParentNode',   child:  'HierarchyNode'   },
  siblingsOrder:    {   by: 'SequenceNumber',    direction: 'ASC'   },
  directory:        '_Hierarchy' }

4. Standard Hierarchies in S/4HANA-

SAP delivers several predefined hierarchies:

  • Cost Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For controlling and cost reporting
  • Profit Center Hierarchy ‚Äì For profitability analysis
  • GL Account Hierarchy ‚Äì For financial statements
  • Product Hierarchy ‚Äì For material classification
  • EHS Location Hierarchies ‚Äì For Environment, Health & Safety compliance

5. Custom Hierarchies-

Business requirements often demand custom hierarchies:

  • Example: A sales region hierarchy combining geography and product lines.
  • Implemented using CDS Views by developing a relation between Dimension Views and Hierarchy View.

6. Why Hierarchies Matter?

  • Enable drill-down reporting in SAC or Fiori Multidimensional Reports/AFO.
  • Support aggregations at multiple levels
  • Provide flexibility for planning and analytics

7. Technical Details: Where Hierarchies Are Stored-

  • HRRP_NODE_N Table: Stores Parent Node info, hierarchy node level details, and relationships between nodes(Example where GL Account/Profit Center/Cost Center Hierarchy details are stored).
  • HRRP_DIR_N Table: Stores Hierarchy Directory info (name, version, metadata).

üëâWhen you activate or create a hierarchy (standard or custom), these tables are updated.

  • HRRP_NODE_N = Node-level details (Parent-Child relationships)
  • HRRP_DIR_N = Directory-level details (Hierarchy header info)

8. Hierarchy Components & Annotations-

  • A well-defined hierarchy in CDS has multiple views:

Source(Master Data) View: Provides key fields and relationships (Eg GL Account/Cost Center/Product related details).
Hierarchy View: Contains the relationships and parent‚Äìchild links. Eg - Hierarchy(Child) Node, Parent Node, Node levels etc.
Directory View: Provides metadata about hierarchy variants -- Optional.
Text Views for labeling nodes and directory entries . Eg: GL account and it's text/ Cost center and it's text etc.

Proper annotations (@Hierarchy.parentChild, @ObjectModel.dataCategory: #HIERARCHY) control recursion, sibling order, orphan handling, and directory association

Notes:

  • Parent‚ÄìChild Hierarchy: Supported in CDS for analytics; recursive structure.
  • Level-Based Hierarchy: Not supported in CDS for analytical consumption (only parent‚Äìchild works for drill-down).
  • Orphan nodes = Nodes without a parent.
  • A Parent Node can have multiple Hierarchy Nodes/Child nodes but a hierarchy node cannot have multiple parents
  • A node can appear under different parents in different hierarchy versions, not in the same hierarchy( It usually refers to alternate hierarchy versions or variants, not simultaneous parents in the same hierarchy. For example:

Hierarchy Variant/Version 1: Region ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City

Hierarchy Variant/Version 2: Sales Channel ‚Üí Country ‚Üí City.This is managed via Hierarchy Directory.

  • A CDS hierarchy cannot serve as the underlying source for building another CDS hierarchy.

Next Article (Part 2)

  • How to activate Standard hierarchies and develop Custom Hierarchies in CDS Views (S4 Hana EA).
  • How to consume hierarchies in SAC

entry.title: Source-Side Filtering vs. Dynamic Topics &Filtering with SAP Advanced Event Mesh and ASAPIO Addon
entry.content:
As more and more organizations modernize their integration landscapes whether they are SAP or non-SAP eco systems, Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming an essential approach to achieving real-time, scalable, and loosely coupled data exchange. Traditional master data distribution‚Äîoften based on scheduled or API-driven replication‚Äîcan no longer keep up with the dynamic needs of digital ecosystems that demand instant synchronization across hybrid SAP and non-SAP environments.

By leveraging SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), and ERP event-on for AEM, enterprises can easily shift toward event-based master data distribution to ensure that updates in systems of records are propagated intelligently, only where and when they are needed. This trend not only reduces system load and redundancy but also enables fine-grained control through mechanisms like source-side filtering and dynamic topic filtering within brokers, which together make EDA a cornerstone for next-generation integration strategies.

Three years ago, I shared a blog on the SAP Event Enablement Add-On for SAP Event Mesh. Since then, SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) has rapidly gained growth as an enterprise-grade event broker with the capability to connect applications, data, and devices across diverse landscapes. 

In this blog, I would like to revisit the ASAPIO Add-On, specifically in the context of integration SAP Advanced Event Mesh. While the add-on continues to be powered by ASAPIO technology, its usage patterns and relevance have evolved alongside AEM's growing adoption. Most of the functionalities are similar but with the ability to build custom payloads and to connect to AEM, it unlocks the value of moving data in real-time from large to very large use cases.

@Benedikt_Sprung   has already published an excellent step-by-step guide on setting up and using the add-on with AEM. Instead of duplicating that content, my focus here will be on a key design consideration: the filtering options available with the add-on and AEM and how they can be applied effectively in real-world scenarios. 

 

Why filtering matters?

Typically, Event-driven architectures (EDA) topics define how events are organized. The way we design and manage topics has a profound impact on scalability, governance, and maintainability. 

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with ASAPIO add-on, two patterns come into discussion with event filtering: source-side filtering (on sender SAP applications) and Dynamic Topics & Filtering (within AEM brokers).

This post explores the difference between these two approaches, when to use each, and how AEM enables more intelligent event distribution in enterprise landscapes.

 

Option 1: Source-Side Filtering on Event Producer

Source-Side filtering usually means the producer (event source) decides dynamically at publish time whether an event should be triggered. Often, a filter based on payload data will be applied to the event liberation.

With ASAPIO add-on, you can use a check function module in header attributes to filter on attributes of the Business Object. For example, you can add the Attribute ID to your Header Attribute customizing in event add-on for ERP: BOR_ATTRIBUTE_<BOR Attribute from SWO1>

 

In this case, only the material data with material group 004 will be triggered. The event broker (AEM) will not receive any data outside of material group 004.

Option 2: Dynamic Topics & Filtering on Event Broker

With this option, the producer (event source) decides at publish time which topic an event should be sent to. Often, topic names are built using runtime data (e.g., customer ID, region, product type).

With ASAPIO add-on, you can set up dynamic topics easily with Field Mapping. It helps you define different layers of the topics and make dynamic filtering easier later during consumption.

 

Based on event context, events can be published to different topics into SAP AEM. Consumers then subscribe only to the events they care about. In above example, topics are built dynamically with the Sales Org ID. If a consumer wants all the data of Sales Order update of Org 1000, it can subscribe to topic /UPDATE/V1/JSON/sap-bo-event/ERD100/1000/BUS2032/>.

In this case, all events are still published to the broker but they can be sorted/routef based on the structure of the topics.

 

When to Use Which?

Source Side Filtering typically works well when consumers are highly specialized and fixed. You don't expect new applications to be added in the future. And in the case when broker load and network traffic is a concern, you can use this option to reduce overhead.

In contrast, dynamic topics & filtering helps you operate at enterprise scale (hundreds of apps, regions, business lines). You want to use this option when you want producers to stay simple and consumers to self-serve. with SAP AEM, it can support very large scale use cases. Using this option will help you have better governance and discoverability on events. 

Dynamic topics & filtering is recommended in most of the use cases as it supports better scalability and flexibility in an EDA integration. To support this option, SAP AEM has its Smart Topics feature to organize event topics. The Topic Taxonomy can be described with none+verb+properties. AEM relies on hierarchical topic structures(using  ‚Äú/‚Äù separators) to enable dynamic routing, filtering, and fine-tuned subscriptions.

An Example of master data event topics could be:

  • materialmaster / updated / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>
  • materialmaster / created / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>

With a defined structure, subscribers can filter based on dynamic topics that they are interested in:

This allows flexibility of subscription and allows consumers to self-serve as well.

 

Conclusion and key takeaways

While source-side filtering gives flexibility, it often leads to topic sprawl and tighter coupling. With SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, enterprises can adopt Smart Topics with Dynamic Topics & Filtering ‚Äî a governance-friendly, scalable way to manage events. This approach keeps producers simple and empowers consumers at enterprise scale.

In most of the use cases, master data distribution is a fan-out pattern, in this case Dynamic Topics & Filtering will provide more flexibility to distribute the data based on needs without tight coupling with producers. Below is a reference architecture for a fan-out scenario and with dynamic topic filtering and multiple integration options, you will be able to easily send to the relevant data to consumers.

 

Happy Eventing!!

SAP Integration Suite SAP S/4HANA Event-driven architecture

entry.title: Assertion failed: The installer is started with enabled database environment variables in SWPM
entry.content:
Hi Folks,

I would like to share a knowledge base article regarding the issues while performing Classical Migration using Export/Import method and SWPM tool.

Scenario:

We have an ABAP system for which we have taken export using SWPM on source server and here we are doing an SAP system installation while importing the exported data using SWPM tool (Installation + Migration), it throws below error while import.

Assertion failed: The installer is started with enabled database environment variables, which is not supported

Environment: Windows server 2019

Cause:

This issue occurred because there was already a System on target host with the same SID which was not properly uninstalled and cleaned up, so there were few Sybase database environment variables remained in the target host Registry Editor(regedit) in windows server which was not properly cleaned up during uninstallation.

Solution:

There are two ways in which this issue can be resolved.

  1. The OS level user from which you are running SWPM, if it contains that environment variables and regedit (Registry) entries of old system SID, running SWPM with another user having same privileges fixes the issue.
  2. Remove the environment variables and entries of Old SID from regedit and restart SWPM and try again.

Additional Information:

You might come across a situation where your target system is corrupted, or system failure happens and you may loss the important encrypted data which is copied from source.  

While importing the data, SWPM provides you key id and key value which you need to take a note of and keep it in a safer place.

The secure storage will be encrypted with the following key:

 Key ID:

YYYYMMDD_HHMMSS_<SID>_INSTALLER

 Key Value:

***********************************************

Make a backup of above Key ID and 58-character Key Value and keep it in a secure place for disaster recovery.

When you are in the process of system installation and want to use this system as source for a system copy or system rename, you must provide this backup to restore access to the encrypted data in the copied system.

Thanks & Regards,

Tanmay Gupta

SAP

entry.title: Und dann? - Generative KI erkl√§ren mit Snap!GPT
entry.content:
Generative K√ºnstliche Intelligenz (KI) ist momentan in aller Munde. Menschen verwenden Large Language Models (LLMs) regelm√§√üig in ihrem Alltag. Sie helfen uns, E-Mails zu schreiben oder Urlaube zu planen. Wir benutzen sie als Sparringspartner um unsere Ideen weiterzuentwickeln und mit ihnen gemeinsam zu programmieren. 

Um generative KI in einer produktiven und sinnvollen Art und Weise zu verwenden, ist es wichtig, dass wir ihre grundlegenden Prinzipien, Vorteile und Limitationen verstehen. 

‚ÄÉ

Snap!GPT

Einer der wichtigsten Mechanismen in diesen Systemen ist die sogenannte Next Token Prediction, also die Vorhersage des wahrscheinlichsten n√§chsten Worts oder "Tokens" in einer Sequenz  basierend auf dem vorherigen Text und mithilfe statistischer Sprachmodelle.  

Die folgenden Materialien erkl√§ren das Konzept eines statistischen Sprachmodells und einer Next Token Prediction anhand von 30 M√§rchen der Gebr√ºder Grimm: 

  • Paper ‚ÄúSnap!GPT ‚Äì Bausteine f√ºr generative K√ºnstliche Intelligenz" (IBIS):
    https://www.informatischebildung.de/index.php/ibis/article/view/31 
  • Starter-Projekt mit allen ben√∂tigten Bl√∂cken: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=SnapGPT%20%2d%20MW 
  • L√∂sungsprojekt (mit Musik-Skripten und Stift-Objekt):
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=SnapGPT%20%2d%20IBIS&editMode&noRun 
  • Video (EN):
    https://www.youtube.com/live/0ft0J3rh3WY?t=1971s  

 

Worteinbettungen (Word Embeddings)

Obwohl dieses Modell grammatikalisch korrekte S√§tze bilden kann, ist es offensichtlich nicht besonders nah an modernen LLMs. Diese ben√∂tigen Monate von Training mit einem Korpus so gro√ü wie das gesamte Internet und statistischen Modellen, die Billionen von Token enthalten. 

Zudem arbeiten moderne LLMs in der Trainingsphase mit mehreren neuronalen Netzen,  die numerische Eingaben brauchen. Deshalb werden sogenannte Worteinbettungen (Word Embeddings) verwendet, in denen W√∂rter und Ausdr√ºcke als Vektoren repr√§sentiert sind. 

In diesem Projekt kannst du mit einem kleinen Set von Worteinbettungen experimentieren. Es enth√§lt ca. 20 000 W√∂rter und ihre jeweilige Vektorrepr√§sentation. Jeder Vektor hat 300 Dimensionen, die Features genannt werden. In Snap! wird das als eine Liste mit 300 Elementen ausgedr√ºckt, jedes Element ist eine Dezimalzahl zwischen -1 und 1). 

Die Orientierung der W√∂rter und ihre Abst√§nde und Verh√§ltnisse zueinander codieren ihre Semantik. In anderen Worten, Vektoren, die nahe beinander liegen stehen f√ºr Synonyme oder √§hnliche W√∂rter,  die Vektoren von W√∂rtern mit sehr unterschiedlicher Bedeutung haben einen gro√üen Abstand zueinander. 

Die 300 Features der Vektoren der W√∂rter "dog" (blau) und "tree" (pink) √ºbereinander geplottet.

  • Link zum Projekt Worteinbettungen: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/project?username=jadga&projectname=Worteinbettung%20%2d%20DE 
    (Das Projekt ist adaptiert von ecraft2learn, Ken Kahn, Universit√§t Oxford (https://ecraft2learn.github.io/ai/))

 

√úber den Transformer

Moderne LLMs nutzen eine sogenannte Transformer-Architektur (GPT steht f√ºr generative pre-trained transformer) - zwei neuronale Netze (NN), die zusammenarbeiten.

Grober √úberblick √ºber die Transformer-Architektur. Eingaben (I) werden an das Encoder Neural Network gegeben und dort in verarbeitbare Einheiten umgewandelt. Die Ergebnisse werden an das Decoder Neural Network √ºbergeben, das dann eine neue Ausgabe (O) generieren kann.

 

Encoder

Die Texteingabe wird in einzelne Einheiten aufgeteilt (Tokenisierung), bevor sie an das Encoder NN √ºbergeben werden. Dort werden die Token als Vektoren (Worteinbettung) codiert. 

Der Satz "Alonzo isst ein Gummib√§rchen" enth√§lt 4 Token. Jedem dieser Token wird ein Vektor zugewiesen im ersten Schritt der Codierung im Encoder Neural Network.

W√ºrden nur Worteinbettungen verwendet, w√ºrden die beiden folgenden S√§tze dieselben Vektoren enthalten und dadurch gleich codiert werden, obwohl sie sehr unterschiedliche Bedeutungen haben: 

Alonzo isst ein Gummib√§rchen.  vs.  Ein Gummb√§rchen isst Alonzo. 

Die Positions-Codierung stellt sicher, dass das nicht passiert. Ein individueller Positionsvektor wird jedem Token in der Sequenz zugewiesen, um die √úbersicht √ºber die Reihenfolge der W√∂rter in einem Satz zu behalten. 

 

Einige W√∂rter erhalten ihre Bedeutung aus dem Kontext eines Satzes. Beispielsweise kann das Wort "Bank" mehrere Bedeutungen haben; die passende kann aus den umgebenden W√∂rtern im Satz abgeleitet werden. Enth√§lt der Satz zum Beispiel zus√§tzlich die W√∂rter "√úberweisung", "Geld" oder "sparen", k√∂nnen wir davon ausgehen, dass das Finanzinstitut gemeint ist. Sind die anderen W√∂rter "sitzen", "Park" oder "Erholung", ist die Bedeutung wohl eher Sitzgelegenheit. 

Einige W√∂rter haben ohne Bezugsw√∂rter in einer Sequenz kaum eine eigene Bedeutung. Pronomina wie "sie" beispielsweise erlangen ihre Bedeutung von den W√∂rtern, auf die sie sich beziehen. 

Der Self-Attention Vektor wird vom Encoder NN berechnet, um die Beziehung von jedem Token in einer Sequenz zu jedem anderen Token in dieser Sequenz darzustellen. In anderen Worten legt er fest, inwieweit die anderen W√∂rter eines Satzes zur Bedeutung eines bestimmten Wortes beitragen. 

Alonzo and seine Freund:innen haben Gummib√§rchen. Er isst sie gerne.

In diesem Fall k√∂nnte sich das Wort "sie" auf Gummib√§rchen (wahrscheinlicher) oder seine Freund:innen (weniger wahrscheinlich) beziehen. Der Self-Attention Vektor in diesem Fall wird einen hohen √Ñhnlichkeitswert (Similarity Score) zwischen den W√∂rtern "Gummib√§rchen" und "sie" aufweisen.

 

Decoder

Die Ausgabe des Encoder NNs (Worteinbettung, Positionscodierung, Self-Attention Vektor) wird an das Decoder Neuronale Netz gef√ºttert, das die tats√§chliche Vorhersage des n√§chsten Tokens √ºbernimmt. 

Um das Decoder NN zu trainieren, wird ein Prozess, der als Maskierung bezeichnet wird, genutzt. 
Der Decoder erh√§lt eine bekannte Eingabe, in der bestimmte W√∂rter versteckt (maskiert) wurden, und muss diese maskierten W√∂rter vorhersagen. Falls er den falschen Token vorhersagt, werden die Gewichte des neuronalen Netzes so lange angepasst, bis der Decoder den wahrscheinlichsten n√§chsten Token korrekt vorhersagen kann. 

Hier ist eine vertiefte und mathematischere Erkl√§rung dar√ºber, wie Transformer genau funktionieren (auf Englisch): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zxQyTK8quyY

 

Weitere Materialien:

ELIZA:

Fr√ºhe Chatbots wie ELIZA von Joseph Weizenbaum (1964) nutzen einen anderen, nicht-statistischen Ansatz, um nat√ºrliche Sprache zu verarbeiten. Sie imitieren menschliche Konversationen, indem sie Sprachmuster erkennen und auf diese mit vordefinierten Teilantworten reagieren. Die DOCTOR Version von ELIZA beispielsweise simuliert Konversationen basierend auf der Idee von Therapeut:innen, die kontinuierlich R√ºckfragen stellen bezugnehmend auf die urspr√ºngliche Eingabe der Nutzer:innen. 

Diese Version von ELIZA versucht Muster zu identifizieren und R√ºckfragen basierend auf diesen Mustern und bezugnehmend auf die Eingabe der Nutzer:innen zu geben

  • Teste diese Snap! Implementierung von ELIZA und versuche Unterschiede zur statistischen Next-Token Prediction zu identifizieren: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=Eliza%202023&editMode&noR...

 

GPT unplugged:

Menschen sind verh√§ltnism√§√üig gut darin, n√§chste Tokens vorherzusagen; unsere F√§higkeit h√§ngt aber stark vom sogenannten Kontextfenster ab, ein Begriff, der auch in LLMs eine Rolle spielt. Das Kontextfenster beschreibt die Anzahl der Tokens, die ber√ºcksichtigt werden (k√∂nnen),  um den n√§chsten Token vorherzusagen. 

In unserem Snap!GPT ist das maximale Kontextfenster 4 W√∂rter. Moderne LLMs haben Kontextfenster, die aus mehreren tausend Token bestehen k√∂nnen. Mit der folgenden unplugged Aktivit√§t soll das Konzept des Kontextfensters verdeutlicht werden. 

Ben√∂tigtes Material: 1 Blatt Papier und ein Stift pro teilnehmender Person.

Alle Teilnehmenden schreiben ein Wort auf ihr jeweiliges Papier und geben es an die n√§chste Person weiter. In der ersten Runde soll das Kontextfenster (Anzahl der W√∂rter, die eine Person sieht, bevor sie ihr eigenes Wort anh√§ngt) ein Wort sein. 

Das bedeutet, die n√§chste Person schreibt ihr Wort unter das vorherige Wort und faltet das Papier so, dass das erste Wort nicht mehr zu sehen ist, nur das Wort, das sie eben hinzugef√ºgt hat. Dann wird das Papier an die n√§chste Person weitergegeben. Wiederholt diesen Prozess ungef√§hr 12 Mal. Entfaltet dann die Papiere und lest einige der generierten S√§tze laut vor. Versucht den sinnvollsten Satz mit einem Kontextfenster von 1 zu finden. 

Wiederholt dann das ganze Spiel mit einer leichten Adaption. Diesmal schreibt die erste Person 4 W√∂rter (jedes in eine neue Zeile). Die n√§chste Person f√ºgt ihr Wort hinzu und faltet das Papier dann so, dass das erste Wort versteckt ist und die anderen 4 W√∂rter sichtbar bleiben. Wiederholt diesen Prozess ungef√§hr 10 Mal. Entfaltet dann die Papiere und lest einige S√§tze laut vor. Versucht wieder den inhaltlich und grammatikalisch besten Satz zu finden. 

Ergeben die S√§tze mehr Sinn, wenn das Kontextfenster gr√∂√üer ist? 
-> Ja, gr√∂√üere Kontextfenster erm√∂glichen es uns, pr√§ziser den n√§chsten Token vorherzusagen. Dadurch k√∂nnen entweder √ºber semantische oder statistische Methoden grammatikalisch bessere S√§tze gebildet werden (z.B. Subjekt, Pr√§dikat, Objekt Struktur, Einleitung von Nebens√§tzen,...)

Machen wir Menschen das wie ein LLM Sprache generiert?
-> Nein, wir arbeiten mit syntaktischem und semantischem Verst√§ndnis von Sprache, nicht mit statistischen Modellen. Menschen arbeiten mit Sprachmustern (Grammatik) und k√∂nnen aus wenigen Beispielen lernen, √§hnliche S√§tze zu bilden, LLMs ben√∂tigen gro√üe Mengen von Trainingsdaten, um Token basierend auf ihren statistischen Modellen vorherzusagen.

Auf der linken Seite ist das Ergebnis der unplugged Aktivit√§t mit Kontextfenster 1 zu sehen, es is keine koh√§rente Satzstruktur erkennbar. Das Papier auf der rechten Seite zeigt das Ergebnis der Aktivit√§t mit Kontextfenster 4. Hier sind Satz-(Sub-)Strukturen vorhanden. 

SoekiaGPT:

Ein didaktisches Sprachmodell entwickelt von Michael Hielscher (PH Schwyz) und die Inspiration f√ºr Snap!GPT. SoekiaGPT m√∂chte ebenfalls das Prinzip der Next Token Prediction von LLMs basierend auf M√§rchen (und Wetterberichten) erfahrbar machen:
https://www.soekia.ch/GPT/ 

 

Snap!GPT Mal-App:

Mit dieser Snap!GPT Mal-App kann basierend auf Richtungen des n√§chsten Liniensegments Gekritzel generiert werden. Der Input, der als Grundlage f√ºr das statistische Modell genutzt wird, wird selbst von Benutzer:innen gezeichnet.

Diese Aktivit√§t kann als Einstieg f√ºr eine Diskussion √ºber gute Einstiegszeichnungen verwendet werden. Warum ist es schwer, geschlossene Strukturen zu generieren? Warum ist das Programm in der Lage, buchstaben-√§hnliche Strukturen zu erzeugen, aber keinen tats√§chlichen Text?

Eingabe f√ºr die Snap!GPT Kritzel-App, Ergebnis nach 2000 Wiederholungen der Next Token Prediction und eine Sammlung aller Ergebnisse eines Workshops

  • Teste die Mal-App unter: 
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=bromagosa&ProjectName=Drawing%20AI&embedMo... 

 

 

 

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: What‚Äôs next? ‚Äì Generative AI with Snap!GPT
entry.content:
Generative AI is everywhere right now. People incorporate Large Language Models (LLMs) in their daily routines, they help us write e-mails and plan our trips, we use them as sparring partners to pitch our ideas or develop code together with them.

In order to use generative AI in a productive and meaningful way, it is important that we understand its underlying principles, advantages and especially limitations.

 

Snap!GPT

One of the major mechanisms in those systems is what we call next token prediction ‚Äì based on preceding text, the most probable next word or ‚Äútoken‚Äù in a sequence is selected with the help of statistical language models.

The following resources aim to explain the concept of statistical language models and next token prediction with 30 fairy tales of the brothers Grimm:

  • Paper ‚ÄúSnap!GPT ‚Äì Building blocks for generative AI‚Äù:
    https://dam.sap.com/mac/u/a/d7aqWvd?rc=10&doi=SAP1257583
  • Starter Project with all required blocks: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=SnapGPT%20%2d%20MW%20%2d%20EN&editMode&noRun
  • Solution Project (containing music script and pen sprite):
    https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=SnapGPT-Microworld-IBIS-EN-Solution
  • Video:
    https://www.youtube.com/live/0ft0J3rh3WY?t=1971s  

 

Word Embeddings

Obviously, although only generating grammatically correct sentences, this isn‚Äôt anywhere close to a modern LLM. They require months of training with a corpus as large as the whole internet and their statistical models contain trillions of tokens.

Additionally, modern LLMs include several neural networks in their pre-training that require numerical values. Therefore, they use so-called word embeddings, vector representations of words and expressions.

In this project you can explore a small set of word embeddings. It contains about 20 000 words and their vector representations. Each vector has 300 dimensions (in Snap! that is expressed as a list with 300 items, each item is a decimal number between -1 and 1).

The arrangement of words and their distances and relations encode their semantics. In other words, vectors with a small distance represent synonyms or closely related words, words with very different meanings also have very different vectors.

The 300 features of the vectors of the words "dog" (blue) and "tree" (pink) plotted on top of each other .

 

  • Link to the word-embeddings project: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jadga&ProjectName=word%20average-EN
    (The project is adapted from ecraft2learn by Ken Kahn from the University of Oxford (https://ecraft2learn.github.io/ai/))

 

About the Transformer

Modern LLMs use a transformer architecture (GPT stands for generative pre-trained transformer), two neural networks working together.

very rough overview of the Transformer architecture. The input is given to the Encoder Neural Network whose results are used by the Decoder Neural Network to generate new output.

The text input is split into individual tokens (tokenization) before it‚Äôs given to the Encoder Neural Network where the tokens are encoded in vectors (word embeddings).

The sentence "Alonzo eats a gummy bear" contains 4 tokens. Each of them is assigned a vector in the first step of the encoding in the Encoder Neural Network

Using just word embeddings, the following two sentences will result in the same vectors although they have a very different meaning: 

Alonzo eats a gummy bear.  vs.  A gummy bear eats Alonzo. 

The positional encoding takes care of that. 
A positional vector is assigned to every word to keep track of the order of words in a sentence.

 

For some words, their meaning depends on the context of the sentence. The word ‚Äúbank‚Äù for example, can have different meanings, which can be inferred from other words around it. Does the sentence e.g. contain the words ‚Äúdeposit‚Äù, ‚Äúmoney‚Äù or ‚Äúwire transfer‚Äù, we‚Äôre probably talking about the financial institution. Are the other words ‚Äúlake‚Äù, ‚Äúwater‚Äù or ‚Äúfish‚Äù it‚Äôs more likely that the word ‚Äúbank‚Äù in this case means riverside.

Some words only get their meaning from other words in a sequence. Pronouns like ‚Äúthem‚Äù for example obtain their meaning from the word they are referring to.

Alonzo and his friends are having gummy bears. He likes eating them.

The self-attention vector is calculated by the Encoder Neural Network to encode the relationship of a token in a sequence with all other tokens in that sequence. It establishes to what extent other words in a sentence contribute to the meaning of a certain word. In this case, the word ‚Äúthem‚Äù could refer to gummy bears (more likely) or his friends (less likely), the self attention vector in this case would have a high similarity score for the words ‚Äúgummy bears‚Äù and ‚Äúthem‚Äù.

 

The output of the Encoder Neural Network is fed into the Decoder Neural Network which is performing the actual next token prediction. 
To train the Decoder Neural Network, a process called Masking is used. The Decoder is given a known input in which certain words were hidden (masked) and has to predict those masked words. If it guesses the wrong token, the weights are adjusted until the Decoder can predict the most likely next token correctly.

Here‚Äôs a more mathematical and in depth explanation of how transformers work: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zxQyTK8quyY

 

Further resources:

ELIZA:

Early chatbots like Joseph Weizenbaum‚Äôs ELIZA (1964) used a different, non-statistical approach to Natural Language Processing (NLP). They were programmed to mimic a human conversational parter by recognizing language patterns and reacting to them in a predefined way. The DOCTOR version of ELIZA for example was simulating conversations based on the idea of a therapist constantly asking follow-up questions referencing the user‚Äôs original input.

This version of ELIZA tries to identify patterns and then asks follow up questions based on these patterns, referring to what the user previously said.

Try this Snap! implementation of ELIZA and try to identify differences to the statistical next-token prediction: https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=jens&ProjectName=Eliza%202023&editMode&noRun

 

GPT unplugged:

Humans are fairly good at predicting next tokens; however our ability highly depends on the context window, a term that also plays a role in LLMs. The context window describes the number of tokens taken into consideration to predict the next one.

In our Snap!GPT, the context window has a maximum of 4 words. Modern LLMs have potential context windows of several thousand tokens.
You can experience the concept of the context window in the following unplugged activity.

Required material: 1 sheet of paper and 1 pen per participating person.

Each participant writes a word on their paper and hands it to the next person. In the first round, the context window (the number of words a person sees before they have to add their word) is one word. That means the next person writes their word under the first word and folds the paper such that the first word isn‚Äôt readable anymore, only the word they added. The then paper is handed to the next person. Repeat this process about 12 times. Then unfold the paper and read a couple of generated sentences out loud. Try to find the most reasonable one with a context window of 1.

Then repeat the whole game but this time, the first person writes 4 words (one per row), the next person adds their word and folds the paper so that only the first word is hidden, the other 4 words will stay visible. Repeat this process about 10 times. Then unfold the papers and read the sentences out loud.

Do they make more sense? If yes, why do you think that is the case?
-> Larger context window allows us to make more precise predictions of the next token.

Do we do this the way an LLM does that?
-> No, we work with syntactic and semantic understanding of language, not with statistical models. Humans learn language patterns (grammar) and can form similar sentences from very few examples, LLMs need a huge training base to predict tokens based on their statistical language model.

On the left side you can see the output of the unplugged activity when only seeing the previous word. No coherent sentence or even substructure can be formed. The paper on the right shows the result of a context window of 4 words.

‚ÄÉ

SoekiaGPT:

A didactical language model and the basis for Snap!GPT, also exploring the next token prediction concept of LLMs: https://bootstrapworld.org/SoekiaGPT/

Originally developed by Michael Hielscher (PH Schwyz), translated by the bootstrap community.

 

Snap!GPT Drawing App:

This Snap!GPT based drawing app lets you explore the generation of scribbles based on predicting the direction for the next line segment. You will draw an input that is used as a basis for the statistical model and by that will be able to generate custom data for your next-token prediction. This activity can be used to discuss which types of initial sketches are better than others. Why it's very hard to recreate closed shapes. Or why the program is not able to generate actual text but letter-like structures. 

Input for the scribbling Snap!GPT, output 2000 iterations of the next token prediction and a mural with a collection of workshop results.

Try the drawing app at: 
https://snap.berkeley.edu/snap/snap.html#present:Username=bromagosa&ProjectName=Drawing%20AI&embedMode&noExitWarning 

‚ÄÉ

 

 

‚ÄÉ

‚ÄÉ

entry.title: ACL Proposal for Gateway in ASCS
entry.content:
One of my customers operates the gateway of the production systems in the ASCS instance as described in https://help.sap.com/docs/SLTOOLSET/910828cec5d14d6685da380aec1dc4ae/bf1d359ac8384441a781ae3b0b5bd1b5.html? version=CURRENT_VERSION&locale=en-US.


The customer has not yet maintained Reginfo + Secinfo and would like to do so. Logging on the development and test system as well as the production system has been running since summer. Logically, gateway logging via SMGW does not register any connections. Now I am wondering how logging and the ACL proposal can be operated in this operating scenario.


Is there a best practice approach for this?


Can the gw/logging + gw/sim_mode parameter be configured in the ASCS instance profile? If so, how should I handle the logs? Should I put them all in one directory so that AS-ABAP can generate the proposals?
It may be due to my Google skills, but I have not yet found any information on this.

Thank you in advance!

entry.title: Re: Why wouldn't a minority indicator populate for every...
entry.content:
Check the following:

  • Purchasing Info Record: Does the minority indicator exist there? If not, the PO line won‚Äôt inherit it.
  • Purchasing Org/Plant assignment: Confirm the vendor master minority indicator is maintained consistently across all org levels.
  • Custom logic: Review exits/BAdIs used in PO creation ‚Äî sometimes the indicator is set only for certain conditions.
  • Field selection: Ensure the field is not suppressed for certain document types or item categories.

entry.title: Driving Extensibility, Innovation and Automation with SAP Build's Clean Core
entry.content:
Below you'll find a summary of what was discussed during our latest Clean Core webinar, led by NTT Data, looking into ways to extend SAP environments and accelerate innovation through SAP Build's Clean Core methodology. 

üóìAgenda Highlights and session recap üóì

  1. Current context: The importance of Clean Core in SAP S/4HANA modernization
    A Clean Core strategy keeps the SAP S/4HANA system free from heavy customizations that complicate upgrades. By reducing technical debt and streamlining updates, organizations gain more stability and agility. This approach lays the foundation for continuous innovation and smooth cloud adoption.

  2. Overview of SAP‚Äôs Side-by-Side extensibility strategy: Pro-Code and Low-Code/No-Code
    SAP's side-by-side extensibility allows organizations to innovate without modifying the core system. It offers both pro-code development for complex scenarios and low-code/no-code tools for business users. This ensures fast, secure innovation while keeping extensions isolated and easy to maintain.

  3. Tools and frameworks for Pro-Code and Low-Code/No-Code developers
    SAP BTP provides a unified set of tools supporting both professional developers and low-code/no-code creators. Pro-code users access advanced IDEs and SDKs, while business users work with visual development tools. Together, these frameworks accelerate development, enhance collaboration, and ensure secure, scalable extensions.

  4. Main components: Build Apps, Build Process Automation, and Build Work Zone
    The SAP Build suite includes three main elements that empower users across the organization. Build Apps enables rapid app creation, Build Process Automation streamlines workflows, and Build Work Zone centralizes access to applications and information. Combined, they create a cohesive digital workplace experience.

  5. Basic principles of SAP Build Apps
    SAP Build Apps focuses on visual, intuitive development to make app creation accessible to more users. It provides drag-and-drop tools, pre-built templates, and seamless integration with SAP and non-SAP systems. With cloud-native deployment and Fiori-aligned design, it supports user-friendly, governed, enterprise-ready innovation.

You can find in the link below the slides shared during the presentation with all of the content presented today by NTT Data. 

Link to presentation

 ‚ÅâÔ∏èStill curious about clean core? ‚ÅâÔ∏è

‚úÖContact your BTP Customer Success Manager for further discussion

‚úÖ Visit SAP Discovery Center Missions on BTP

entry.title: Is AI Just a Power Tool for Enterprise Software?
entry.content:
We all remember that feeling ‚Äì watching our friends build a little wood house next to the sandbox, marveling at how quickly they could assemble it with all the power tools available. Similarly, we can build a small tool shed in a weekend ‚Äì a quick project with readily available resources. But try to build a 2-car garage, and suddenly the reality hits: it‚Äôs a vastly more complex undertaking. Even with every tool imaginable, you'd spend countless hours watching YouTube videos, improvising solutions, and inevitably missing crucial details ‚Äì resulting in a structure that doesn‚Äôt meet the family council's standards.

That‚Äôs precisely how AI currently operates in enterprise software development. It can be an amazing ‚Äúpower tool‚Äù ‚Äì accelerating routine tasks and suggesting code snippets. But it fundamentally cannot build a complex, robust software system on its own.

 

Let‚Äôs break down why. The garage analogy is a powerful one because it illustrates the difference between rapid assembly and true, lasting construction. AI can certainly suggest a quick solution for a simple function ‚Äì like generating boilerplate code or completing a basic API endpoint. However, building a 2-car garage requires deep understanding of structural engineering, material science, and local building codes. Similarly, complex enterprise software projects demand architectural judgment, a comprehensive understanding of business requirements, and meticulous attention to detail ‚Äì qualities that currently reside firmly with human developers.

AI coding assistants speed up routine tasks (boilerplate, suggestions, small functions) but lack long‚Äërange architectural judgment, project context, and ownership required to run an entire project end-to-end. AI is used for bigger, more complex tasks, is introducing architectural anti‚Äëpatterns, duplication which result in maintainability and accelerating technical debt.

Responsibility of the code and using AI at the right time is still the coders responsibility. An expert knows "when to use what tool to get the right result.‚Äù Treating AI as a simple productivity booster ‚Äì not an autonomous architect ‚Äì is crucial.

Ultimately, building complex software requires a deep understanding of the business problem and a commitment to maintainability and scalability ‚Äì qualities that are currently beyond the capabilities of AI. Just as you need a structural engineer to design a garage (or a house), developers need architectural expertise and rigorous testing to ensure the long-term success of any software project.

Don‚Äôt expect AI to build your garage (or House)‚Äì or your enterprise software system. Instead, view it as a valuable tool that can significantly enhance the productivity of skilled developers, but not replace them.

entry.title: Re: Translation for Custom Field (based on CBO) not refle...
entry.content:
Dear @jpriya,

I recreated your case in my environment and tell me if this is the effect you were looking for?

Goal: MultiLang F4 help (EN / IT) for a field in Manage Product Master Data app

  1. Create the field
    • App: Custom Fields
    • Business Context: Master Data: Product General (PRODUCT)
    • New field:
      • Type: Code List
      • Length: as needed

  1. Define list values (in your logon language, for example: English)
    • In the List Values section add rows:
      • Code Value: 01 ‚Äì test, 02 - demo
    • Create and edit.

 

  1. Maintain translations for code descriptions
    • Open the same field again in Custom Fields app
    • Click Translation
    • Select target language IT Italian.
    • For each Code Value enter the Italian Description
    • Save the translations

 

 

  1. Add the field to the Product UI
    • App: Manage Product Master Data ->Adapt UI.
    • Save and publish the UI adaptation.
  2. Test and Result
    • Log on in English ->F4 shows English descriptions

 

    • Log on in Italian ->F4 shows Italian descriptions

 

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: Re: Smarter Built-In Support in C4C: A Unified and Upgraded Experience
entry.content:
Thanks for taking the time to share this. I really understand why the change feels disruptive, especially if you were used to handling everything inside C4C without ever needing SAP for Me. The extra step of customer authorization can feel inconvenient at first, but it is worth remembering that using S-users has always been a requirement, particularly whenever you need support access on a tenant you cannot log into. Another positive and important aspect, which was not mentioned in the blog, is that your cases will now remain available even if you refresh or move your tenant, which was not possible before.

It is also important to say that the previous Built-In Support platform was outdated with no possibility of improvement and was affected by synchronization issues that caused real problems for many customers. This was one of the key reasons why we needed to move to a more reliable foundation, a foundation that is used in multiple SAP solutions.

Just to clarify, this is not a full shift to SAP for Me. You can still create and manage your own cases directly within the application. For managing all cases created by other admin users, aligning C4C with the broader SAP support platform now gives you access to the full case management capabilities of SAP for Me, including far better reporting, clearer escalation paths, and a much more reliable overall experience.

I really appreciate your feedback, it helps us support everyone better through the transition.

entry.title: Is there any standard way to send rework quantities or times from SAP DM to SAP during execution?
entry.content:
Dear Community,

I would like to ask about the standard capabilities of SAP Digital Manufacturing regarding rework confirmations.

In SAP DM, we know there are several standard approaches for handling rework, such as:

  • Disposition-based rework,

  • In-routing rework loops, etc.

If the routing does not contain a dedicated rework operation, SAP DM does not send any rework quantity or rework time to SAP ERP. All confirmations are treated as normal confirmations, and there is no standard flag or indicator to differentiate a ‚Äúsecond time‚Äù confirmation from a rework one.

Is there any standard functionality in SAP DM that allows us to send rework quantities or rework time to SAP side during execution, even when the rework operation is not defined in the original routing?

Any guidance, clarification, or experience-sharing would be greatly appreciated.

Thank you!

entry.title: Clean Core Index, measure usage of SAPScript and SmartForms
entry.content:
Introduction

As part of our Custom Code Lifecycle Management, and especially as part of our Clean Core journey, we try to delete as many obsolete objects as possible. In the end, we try to get rid of almost 30 years of custom development.

Before we can start to renovate our code, we first need to identify and delete any unused object. SAP supports us on this with various tools, like UPL, CCLM on Solution Manager  or the Custom Code Migration app. Sadly, none of the tools is 100% perfect in identifying unused code. For example, classical print reports will be flagged as unused, even if you use them on daily basis. This is because the user doesn't call the report itself. Instead, it gets called in a dynamical manner, after reading the name of report from the customizing

So how can we identify, if a SAPScript or SmartForm is really in use? I wasn't able to find any standard solution. Therefore I created a little tool by myself I want to share with you.

Disclaimer

My solution works on an on-premise system (S/4 HANA 2023 FP1). It consists of few development objects and some of them violates Clean Core principles. Sometimes you need to take a bad pill.

The main work was found in this community post. Thanks to DavidLY for showcasing this

Theory

Each form gets created by some code, typically a dedicated print report. If such a report gets called dynamically, i.e., based on some customizing settings, UPL will not count this as a usage. Same is also true for the forms itself. Often the name of a form to use is configured by customizing. Even if you try to use ABAP code search in ADT, to find a report related to a given form, there is a good chance to get no result.

So how do we know if a given form is still in use or already obsolete and unused since years? In my opinion, one must inspect all created spool objects and try to read the name of the form based on TemSe data.

To access the header information and content of a spool job, tables TST01 and TST03 can be used. Field DTYPE in TST01 indicates the type of spool data. If it starts with OTF%, it is either SAPScript or SmartForms. By this, we know that this is a form, but we still need to find the name of the form used to create the spool. This can be read from content of spool (table TST03).

You can check this by transaction SP01. Double-click on one spool job to open the header information

Navigate to tab "TemSe object" and double-click on spool object name

This will open the list of objects inside the spool request. Mark one object and click on button Contents to inspect the content itself

Have a close look at the second row. You'll find the name of the form, in this example, the name was ZMEDRUCK_US

Similar works also for SmartForms.

As we now know how to identify the form used to create a spool object, we can develop some artifacts to fetch them automatically.

Solution

CDS View

First of all, a CDS view is used to read the spool files and their content. This will be the basis for further processing.

@AbapCatalog.viewEnhancementCategory: [#NONE]
@AccessControl.authorizationCheck: #NOT_REQUIRED
@EndUserText.label: 'List of actively used SAPScript forms'
@Metadata.ignorePropagatedAnnotations: true
@ObjectModel.usageType:{
    serviceQuality: #X,
    sizeCategory: #S,
    dataClass: #MIXED
}
define root view entity ZI_cclm_upl_sapscript
  as select from tst01 as spool
    join         tst03 as data on  spool.dname = data.dname
                               and spool.dpart = data.dpart
{
key spool.dname as SpoolName,
                             key spool.dpart as SpoolPart,
                             key data.drowno as SpoolNo,
                             spool.dtype as SpoolType,
                             spool.dlang as Language,
                             cast( substring( spool.dcretime, 1, 8) as abap.dats ) as CreatedAt,
                             spool.dmodtool as Report,
                             spool.dcreater as CreatedBy,
                            
                             data.ddatalen as DataLength,
                             data.dcontent as Content

  }
where
      spool.dtype like 'OTF%'
  and data.drowno = 1

 

Class

The following class is used to read and process the data. It provides methods to read spool usage per day as well as methods to extract form name based on spool content.

 

We run this code on a daily basis and store the results in a custom table. As this might be different to your requirement, I only provide a method stub for this. You might want to add whatever code you like to store the result.

"! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Class to extract usage of SAPScript forms</p>
"! This class is part of BOMAGs clean core strategy. It helps to collect all actively used
"! SAPScript forms. With this class, the results can be stored in table ZSSTAT
CLASS zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL
  CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    TYPES:
      "! data type for usage statistic
      BEGIN OF
        ty_usage,

        sapscriptform TYPE swncentryid,
        report        TYPE progname,
        lastcreatedat TYPE date,
        lastcreatedby TYPE syuname,
        totalusage    TYPE int4,
      END OF ty_usage.

    "! Table type for usage statistics aggregated by user, date and SAPScript form
    TYPES tyt_usage TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_usage WITH KEY sapscriptform.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">get SAPscript usage by date</p>
    "! This method reads all existing TemSe objects to collect all used SAPScript
    "! forms during the diven time period.
    "! This method can't be used to query historical data stored in ZSSTAT. Instead
    "! it can be used to read actual data
    "! @parameter usage_from | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">spool created from date</p>
    "! @parameter usage_to   | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">spool created to date</p>
    "! @parameter usage      | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">table containing aggregated data</p>
    METHODS get_actual_usage_by_date IMPORTING usage_from   TYPE sydate
                                               usage_to     TYPE sydate
                                     RETURNING VALUE(usage) TYPE tyt_usage.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Persist usage statistics to database</p>
    "! This method can be used to store usage statistics to database. It stores actual usage statistics to
    "! table ZSSTAT. If record already exists, it gets aggregated (update), otehrwise it creates new records
    "! @parameter usage_list | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">List with actual usage data to store</p>
    METHODS write_usage_to_db IMPORTING usage_list TYPE tyt_usage.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    TYPES:
      "! data type for single spool entry, no aggregated data
      BEGIN OF ty_non_aggregated_usage,
        spool         TYPE zi_cclm_upl_sapscript,
        sapscriptform TYPE tdname,
      END OF ty_non_aggregated_usage.

    "! Table type for spool entries, no aggregation
    TYPES tyt_non_aggreageted_usage TYPE STANDARD TABLE OF ty_non_aggregated_usage.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Get SAPScript form name by content</p>
    "! This method can be used to determine SAPScript form name based on spool content
    "! (content of TemSe object)
    "! @parameter content   | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">content of TemSe object</p>
    "! @parameter form_name | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Name of SAPScript form</p>
    METHODS get_sapscript_name IMPORTING content          TYPE string
                               RETURNING VALUE(form_name) TYPE tdform.

    "! <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">Aggregate usage statistic</p>
    "! This method aggregates (sum) actual usage data to one row for each date, user and SAPScript
    "! @parameter spool | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">list of non aggregated usage data</p>
    "! @parameter usage | <p class="shorttext synchronized" lang="de">aggregated usage data</p>
    METHODS aggregate_usage IMPORTING !spool       TYPE tyt_non_aggreageted_usage
                            RETURNING VALUE(usage) TYPE tyt_usage.

ENDCLASS.


CLASS zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript IMPLEMENTATION.
  METHOD get_actual_usage_by_date.
    DATA spool TYPE tyt_non_aggreageted_usage.

    SELECT * FROM zi_cclm_upl_sapscript
      WHERE createdat BETWEEN @usage_from AND @usage_to
      INTO TABLE (sapscript_list).

    LOOP AT sapscript_list ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<single_form>).

      IF <single_form>-datalength <= 0.
        CONTINUE.
      ENDIF.

      DATA(encoded_content) = ||.

      " prepare conversion RAW to STRING
      DATA(encoded_object) = cl_abap_conv_in_ce=>create( encoding = '4103'
                                                         input    = <single_form>-content ).

      " convert RAW to string
      encoded_object->read( IMPORTING data = encoded_content ).

      DATA(formname) = get_sapscript_name( substring( val = encoded_content
                                                      len = 1000 ) ).

      spool = VALUE #( BASE spool
                       ( spool         = <single_form>
                         sapscriptform = formname )  ).

      CLEAR formname.
    ENDLOOP.

    usage = aggregate_usage( spool  ).
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD get_sapscript_name.
    " SAPScript
    FIND 'IN01' IN content MATCH OFFSET DATA(pos).
    IF pos > 0.
    ELSE.
      " SmartForm
      FIND 'IN04' IN content MATCH OFFSET pos.
    ENDIF.

    IF pos > 0.
      pos += 5.
      form_name = substring( val = content
                             off = pos
                             len = 16 ).
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD aggregate_usage.
    LOOP AT spool ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<spool>).

      " try to get last usage of a given form, user and date
      ASSIGN usage[ sapscriptform = <spool>-sapscriptform
                    lastcreatedby = <spool>-spool-createdby
                    lastcreatedat = <spool>-spool-createdat ] TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

      " record already found, aggregate
      IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <usage> IS ASSIGNED.
        <usage>-totalusage += 1.
        <usage>-report      = <spool>-spool-report.
      ELSE.
        " new record, add to list
        usage = VALUE #( BASE usage
                         ( sapscriptform = <spool>-sapscriptform
                           report        = <spool>-spool-report
                           lastcreatedat = <spool>-spool-createdat
                           lastcreatedby = <spool>-spool-createdby
                           totalusage    = 1 ) ).
      ENDIF.

      UNASSIGN <usage>.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD write_usage_to_db.
    " 1. read all existing records from ZSSTAT to update these
    IF lines( usage_list ) > 0.
      SELECT * FROM zsstat
        FOR ALL ENTRIES IN @usage_list
        WHERE sysid    = -sysid
          AND zdate    = @usage_list-lastcreatedat
          AND account  = @usage_list-lastcreatedby
          AND entry_id = @usage_list-sapscriptform
          AND tcode    = 'SAPSCRIPT'
        INTO TABLE (usage_statistics).
    ENDIF.

    " 2 .loop through newly aggregated usage statistics
    LOOP AT usage_list ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<new_usage_record>).

      ASSIGN usage_statistics[ sysid    = sy-sysid
                               entry_id = <new_usage_record>-sapscriptform
                               account  = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedby
                               zdate    = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedat ] TO FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

      " 2.1 update existing record in database
      IF sy-subrc = 0 AND <usage> IS ASSIGNED.
        <usage>-zcount += <new_usage_record>-totalusage.
        UPDATE zsstat
        SET zcount = <usage>-zcount
            progname = <new_usage_record>-report
        WHERE sysid    = sy-sysid
          AND zdate    = <usage>-zdate
          AND account  = <usage>-account
          AND entry_id = <usage>-entry_id
          AND tcode    = 'SAPSCRIPT'.
      ELSE.

        " 2.2. insert new record to database
        INSERT INTO zsstat VALUES @( VALUE #(
                                        sysid = sy-sysid
                                        zdate = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedat
                                        account = <new_usage_record>-lastcreatedby
                                        entry_id = <new_usage_record>-sapscriptform
                                        tcode = 'SAPSCRIPT'
                                        zcount = <new_usage_record>-totalusage
                                        progname = <new_usage_record>-report ) ).

      ENDIF.
      IF sy-subrc = 0.
        COMMIT WORK.
      ENDIF.

      UNASSIGN <usage>.
    ENDLOOP.
  ENDMETHOD.
ENDCLASS.

Report

We want to create a usage statistics. This means we need to read data for a certain period on a regular basis (like once per day). As we're on-premise, we need to schedule a job and therefore, we need a small report which uses the class above.

REPORT zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript_aggr.

PARAMETERS:
  pm_from TYPE dats,
  pm_to   TYPE dats.

START-OF-SELECTION.
  DATA(upl) = NEW zbc_cclm_upl_sapscript( ).

  DATA(usage) = upl->get_actual_usage_by_date( usage_from = pm_from
                                               usage_to   = pm_to ).
  upl->write_usage_to_db( usage_list = usage ).

  LOOP AT usage ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<usage>).

    WRITE: / <usage>-lastcreatedat,
    <usage>-lastcreatedby,
    <usage>-sapscriptform,
    <usage>-report,
    <usage>-totalusage.
  ENDLOOP.

Conclusion

Thanks to these small development artifacts, we build a reliable usage statistics for SAPScript and SmartForms. After collecting data for almost 12 months, we now know the forms actively used.

 

I'm still looking for a similar solution for Adobe Forms. If one has some idea on how to check usage here as well, please let me know
